Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Development of Sparsity-Inducing Dual Frames and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Li
1313490

The investigator studies the new notion of sparsity-inducing dual frames and their applications. Theme 1 defines sparsity-inducing dual frames of a non-exact frame. Preliminary studies show that if a signal has a sparse frame representation, then there is a sparsity-inducing dual frame (sparse dual) that produces the exact sparse coefficient when applied to the signal. Optimality issues of sparse duals and common sparse dual frames to classes of signals are examined. Theme 2 develops iterative algorithms for a sparse-dual-based analysis approach in sparse signal recovery. Improvement and convergence analysis of an alternative iterative algorithm are among the goals here. Theme 3 aims to understand the greatly improved sparse signal recovery capacity of the sparse-dual-based analysis method. This appears to be related to some geometric properties of the sparse hyperplane -- the affine subspace of the sparse representation fused with sparse dual information. One goal is to derive algorithms that adaptable to the geometric properties of the sparse hyperplane for greater effectiveness. Theme 4 develops the notion of sparse duals for practical scenarios where signals are merely approximately sparse with frames. Theme 5 develops "arbitrary" filter banks for multi-channel signal/image requisition and multi-channel communication applications. These systems exhibit arbitrary inter-channel relationships because they generally do not satisfy the commonly known multi-rate filter bank constraints rooted in wavelet theories. The challenge lies in actual constructions of realistic or FIR synthesis filters for these systems.

Signal processing generally refers to making a signal easy to handle or of better quality. It is a common task in modern systems that transmit or store information. In this project, the principal novelties introduced to signal processing are the new notion of sparsity-inducing dual frames (sparse duals) and ideas of recovering underlying signals from much smaller samples of the signal. Sparsity-inducing dual frames are sets of optimal and basic signal components used in obtaining the sparsest (the smallest number of nonzero) signal decomposition coefficients. An advantage of sparse duals is that they can improve the recovery of a signal from a small number of samples of the signal. The investigator develops effective methods of sparse signal recovery. Results of the project could lead to simpler and more effective sampling devices, radar systems, commercial imaging techniques, geographic survey and mapping systems, wireless communication systems, multi-sensor/camera surveillance systems, and multi-channel medical image requisition methods. The project provides training opportunities for undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI is deeply grateful to the support of the NSF RUI grant, which is absolutely essential for the progress that the PI is able to make.

The studies center around the development of sparsity-inducing dual frames and applications in sparse signal recovery in the general area of compressed sensing and data sciences. One of the major developments is the introduction of the notion of sparsity-inducing dual frames in the frame theory.  It is highly relevant to concise frame representations of a function.  It is part of tireless efforts in optimal frame expansions in the scientific community. Studies indicate that sparse-dual-based approaches are highly effective.  Techniques discovered in the studies are applied to array signal processing such as effective DOA (direction of arrival) estimation, which is very useful (perhaps highly impactful) in digital communication and in radar signal processing. During the course of the studies, more theoretical results are obtained about the convergence guarantee of some of PI’s previous works on sparsity recovery algorithms.  These are the null-space tuning algorithm with thresholding and feedbacks.  The related algorithms are seen as the most effective sparse signal recovery techniques among all known methods.  The effectiveness is particularly evident for large systems. As part of proposed studies, constructions of arbitrary multi=channel filterbanks via the fusion frame theory are also carried out.

Studies on sparsity-inducing methodologies to sparse signal recovery also led to the discovery of techniques of ?1-tail-minimization (tail-min) approaches. Tail-min techniques are capable of recovering sparse signals that typical known methods will not.  Such observations are also supported by theoretical proofs.

These works by the PI relate to generally data sciences and signal processing applications. Signal processing generally refers to making the signal easy to handle and/or of better quality.  It is everywhere seen in our modern society.  The principal novelties introduced to signal processing in the studies are the notion of sparsity-inducing dual frames (sparse duals) and ideas of recovering underlying signals from much smaller "samples" of the signal. The sparsity-inducing dual frames are a set of optimal and basic signal components used in obtaining the sparsest (the smallest number of nonzero) signal decomposition coefficients.  The inception of sparsity-inducing dual frames is part of PI's continuing efforts in optimal frame expansions studied under several previously sponsored NSF projects. The substance of sparse duals lies in the fact that it has the capacity to greatly advance the effectiveness of the signal recovery through a small number of "samples" of a signal.  The resulting works contribute to the development of effective methods of sparse signal recoveries, and to the advance of the art of new signal detections techniques. These works are to have potentially a noteworthy impact to information technology ranging from designing simplified sampling devices to designing complexity-reduced radar systems and commercial imaging techniques, reduced complexity in geographic survey, mapping, wireless communication, multi-sensor/camera surveillance systems, multi-channel medical image requisition and combinations, and a great number of signal requisition and combination applications.

As an important outcome, the PI engaged each year 3-5 undergraduate students in research. 

Works completed in this award period include:

Fast thresholding algorithms with feedbacks for sparse signal recovery. Jointly with T. Mi and Y. Liu, Applied and Computational Harmonic Analysis, Vol. 37, Issue 1, pp 69-88, July 2014.

Tight and random nonorthogonal fusion frames. Jointly with J. Cahill, P. Casazze and M. Ehler, Trends in Harmonic Analysis and Applications, Contemporary Mathematics, Vol. 650, pp 23 - 36, 2015.

Sparse frame DOA estimations via a rank-one correlation model for low SNR and limited snapshots. Jointly with Cao Zeng, Shengqi Zhu, and Guisheng Liao, Applied and Computational Harmonic Analysis, Vol. 41, Issue 2,  pp362-383, Sept 2016.

Spark-level sparsity and the ?1 tail minimization. Jointly with Chunkit Lai, and Daniel Mondo, in press, Applied and Computational Harmonic Analysis, 2017.

Tight and Full Spark Chebyshev Frames with Real Entries and Worst-Case Coherence Analysis. Jointly with David Ellis and Eric Hayashi, in press, Contemporary Mathematics, volume “Frames and Harmonic Analysis”, 2017.

Fusion Frames and Distributed Sparsity. Jointly with Roza Aceska and Jean-Luc Bouchot, in press, Contemporary Mathematics, volume “Frames and Harmonic Analysis”, 2017.

Stability for Sparsity Inducing Dual Frames. Jointly with David Ellis, Eric Hayashi, and Lanmei Wang, submitted for publication, 2016.

The convergence guarantee of the iterative thresholding algorithm with suboptimal feedbacks for large systems. Jointly with N. Han, and Z. Song, submitted for publication, 2017.

The number of iterations of fast thresholding algorithms with feedbacks. Jointly with N. Han, and Z. Song, submitted for publication, 2017.

Sparse Tensor RPCA for Accelerated Dynamic Cardiac MRI with Separation of Contents and Background. Jointly with Z. Song and Y. Lei, submitted for publication, 2016.

A Null Space Property and Stability for the Tail-minimization Approach in Compressed Sensing. Jointly with D. Ellis and E. Hayashi, submitted for publication, 2017.
